attributes.title: Vaccines—Calling the Shots Preview
attributes.description_short: Examine the science behind vaccinations and the risks of opting out.
attributes.description_long: Diseases that were largely eradicated in the United States a generation ago—whooping cough, measles, mumps—are returning, in part because nervous parents are skipping their children's shots. NOVA takes viewers around the world to track epidemics, explore the science behind vaccinations, hear from parents wrestling with vaccine-related questions, and shed light on the risks of opting out.

attributes.title: Brushes with Death
attributes.description_short: Dorothy Roseman describes her close encounters with vaccine-preventable diseases.
attributes.description_long: Dorothy Roseman describes her close encounters with vaccine-preventable diseases.

attributes.title: Tiny Tattoo Vaccines
attributes.description_short: New miniature vaccines may be administered like painless tattoos.
attributes.description_long: The world can be a dangerous place, full of foes large and little. Take deadly infectious diseases. Host David Pogue considers a new kind of vaccine that might save millions of lives, while eliminating the need for refrigeration and scary needles.
attributes.player_code: <iframe  id='partnerPlayer' frameborder='0' marginwidth='0' marginheight='0' scrolling='no' width='100%' height='100%' src='//player.pbs.org/partnerplayer/28NK6sCBAitUwVuYTM_gww==/?topbar=false&end=0&endscreen=true&start=0&autoplay=false' allowfullscreen></iframe>

attributes.title: Fighting HPV in Bhutan
attributes.description_short: Bhutan is the first developing country to embrace a vaccine to fight cervical cancer.
attributes.description_long: Human papillomavirus, or HPV, can cause cervical cancer. Bhutan is the first developing country to welcome the widespread vaccination of girls against HPV, and cervical cancer rates have dropped. Some countries have resisted the vaccine, but in Bhutan even the royal princess is onboard.

attributes.title: Stabilizing Vaccines with Silk
attributes.description_short: New technology may bypass the need to keep vaccines cold by stabilizing them with silk.
